original: Majjhima Nikāya 125
analyzed: majjhima nikāya
translated: Middle Length Discourses

original: Dantabhūmisutta
analyzed: dantabhūmi sutta
translated: The Tamed One’s Ground

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe
translated: Once the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.

original: Tena kho pana samayena aciravato samaṇuddeso araññakuṭikāyaṁ viharati.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena aciravataḥ samaṇuddesaḥ arañña kuṭikāyam viharati
translated: At that time the novice Aciravata was staying in a wilderness hut.

original: Atha kho jayaseno rājakumāro jaṅghāvihāraṁ anucaṅkamamāno anuvicaramāno yena aciravato samaṇuddeso tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā aciravatena samaṇuddesena saddhiṁ sammodi.
analyzed: atha khalu jayasenaḥ rāja kumāraḥ jaṅghāvihāram anucaṅkamamānaḥ anuvicaramānaḥ yena aciravataḥ samaṇuddeso tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā aciravatena samaṇuddesena saddhim sammodi
translated: Then Prince Jayasena, while walking and wandering for exercise, went to Aciravata and exchanged greetings with him.

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho jayaseno rājakumāro aciravataṁ samaṇuddesaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu jayasenaḥ rāja kumāraḥ aciravatam samaṇuddesam etat avoca
translated: After discussing various topics, he sat down to one side and said to Aciravata,

original: “Sutaṁ metaṁ, bho aggivessana:
analyzed: sutam mā ita bho aggivessana
translated: “Master Aggivessana, I have heard that you don’t approve of sensual pleasures.

original: ‘idha bhikkhu appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto phuseyya cittassa ekaggatan’”ti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhu appamattaḥ ātāpī pahitattaḥ viharantaḥ phuseyya cittassa ekagga tanti
translated: ‘Here a monk, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which consists of rapture and pleasure born of seclusion, accompanied by directed thought and evaluation.’“

original: “Evametaṁ, rājakumāra, evametaṁ, rājakumāra.
analyzed: evam eta rāja kumāra evam eta rāja kumāra
translated: “That’s right, Prince. That’s right.

original: Idha bhikkhu appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto phuseyya cittassa ekaggatan”ti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhu appamattaḥ ātāpī pahitattaḥ viharantaḥ phuseyya cittassa ekagga tanti
translated: Here a monk, while dwelling diligent, ardent, and resolute, would touch with his mind the unthinkability of mind.”

original: “Sādhu me bhavaṁ aggivessano yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ desetū”ti.
analyzed: sādhu me bhavan aggivessanaḥ yathāsutam yathāpariyattam dhammam desetu uti
translated: “It would be good if Master Aggivessana would teach me the Dhamma as he has heard it and mastered it.”

original: “Na kho te ahaṁ, rājakumāra, sakkomi yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ desetuṁ.
analyzed: na kho te aha rāja kumāra sakkomi yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhammam desetu
translated: “I am not able, prince, to teach you the Dhamma as I have heard it and mastered it.

original: Ahañca hi te, rājakumāra, yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ deseyyaṁ, tvañca me bhāsitassa atthaṁ na ājāneyyāsi; so mamassa kilamatho, sā mamassa vihesā”ti.
analyzed: aham ca hi te rāja kumāra yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhammam deseyya tvañca me bhāsitassa attham na ājāneyyāsi saḥ mamassa kilamatho sā mamassa vihesā ati
translated: If I were to teach you the Dhamma as I have heard it and mastered it, you would not understand the meaning of my words, and that would be wearying and troublesome for me.”

original: “Desetu me bhavaṁ aggivessano yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ.
analyzed: desetu me bhavan aggivessanaḥ yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhamma
translated: “Let Master Aggivessana teach me the Dhamma as he has heard it and mastered it.

original: Appevanāmāhaṁ bhoto aggivessanassa bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājāneyyan”ti.
analyzed: appevanāmā aham bhoto aggivessanassa bhāsitassa attham ājāneyyanti
translated: Perhaps I will understand the meaning of his words.”

original: “Deseyyaṁ kho te ahaṁ, rājakumāra, yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ.
analyzed: deseyyam kho te aha rāja kumāra yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhamma
translated: “I will teach you the Dhamma as I have heard it and mastered it.

original: Sace me tvaṁ bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājāneyyāsi, iccetaṁ kusalaṁ;
analyzed: sace me tvam bhāsitassa attham ājāneyyāsi iccā itam kusala
translated: If you understand the meaning of my words, that will be good.

original: no ce me tvaṁ bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājāneyyāsi, yathāsake tiṭṭheyyāsi, na maṁ tattha uttariṁ paṭipuccheyyāsī”ti.
analyzed: no ce me tvam bhāsitassa attham ājāneyyāsi yathāsake tiṭṭheyyāsi na mama tattha uttarim paṭipuccheyyāsi iti
translated: If you don’t understand the meaning of what I say, then just leave it at that. Don’t ask me to explain further.”

original: “Desetu me bhavaṁ aggivessano yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ.
analyzed: desetu me bhavan aggivessanaḥ yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhamma
translated: “Please teach me what you have heard and learned, sir.

original: Sace ahaṁ bhoto aggivessanassa bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānissāmi, iccetaṁ kusalaṁ;
analyzed: sace aham bhotaḥ aggivessanassa bhāsitassa attham ājānissāmi iccā itam kusala
translated: If I understand the meaning of what you say, that’s good.

original: no ce ahaṁ bhoto aggivessanassa bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānissāmi, yathāsake tiṭṭhissāmi, nāhaṁ tattha bhavantaṁ aggivessanaṁ uttariṁ paṭipucchissāmī”ti.
analyzed: no ce aham bhotaḥ aggivessanassa bhāsitassa attham ājānissāmi yathā asake tiṭṭhissāmi na aham tattha bhavantam aggivessanam uttarim paṭipucchissāmi iti
translated: If not, then I’ll just leave it at that. I won’t ask you to explain further.”

original: Atha kho aciravato samaṇuddeso jayasenassa rājakumārassa yathāsutaṁ yathāpariyattaṁ dhammaṁ desesi.
analyzed: atha kho aciravataḥ samaṇuddesaḥ jayasenassa rāja kumārassa yathāsutam yathā pariyattam dhammam desesi
translated: Aciravata then taught the prince what he had heard and learned.

original: Evaṁ vutte, jayaseno rājakumāro aciravataṁ samaṇuddesaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte jayasenaḥ rāja kumāraḥ aciravatam samaṇuddesam etat avoca
translated: When he had finished, the prince said,

original: “aṭṭhānametaṁ, bho aggivessana, anavakāso yaṁ bhikkhu appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto phuseyya cittassa ekaggatan”ti.
analyzed: aṭṭhānam eta bho aggivessana anavakāsaḥ yam bhikkhu appamattaḥ ātāpī pahitattaḥ viharantaḥ phuseyya cittassa ekagga tanti
translated: “It’s impossible, sir, that a diligent, keen, and resolute monk would not touch the deathless.”

original: Atha kho jayaseno rājakumāro aciravatassa samaṇuddesassa aṭṭhānatañca anavakāsatañca pavedetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi.🔽Atha kho aciravato samaṇuddeso acirapakkante jayasene rājakumāre yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
analyzed: atha kho jayasenaḥ rāja kumāraḥ aciravatassa samaṇuddesassa aṭṭhāna tat ca anavakāsa tat ca pavedetvā uṭṭhāya āsanā pakkāmi  atha khalu aciravataḥ samaṇa uddesaḥ acira pakkante jayasene rāja kumāre yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi
translated: Then Prince Jāyasena, having declared to the novice Aciravata his own lack of opportunity and lack of free time, got up from his seat and left.🔽Then, not long after Prince Jāyasena had left, the novice Aciravata went to the Blessed One, bowed down, sat down to one side,

original: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho aciravato samaṇuddeso yāvatako ahosi jayasenena rājakumārena saddhiṁ kathāsallāpo taṁ sabbaṁ bhagavato ārocesi.
analyzed: ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho aciravataḥ samaṇuddesaḥ yāvatakaḥ ahosi jayasenena rāja kumārena saddhim kathā sallāpo tam sabbam bhagavataḥ ārocesi
translated: and reported his entire conversation with Prince Jāyasena.

original: Evaṁ vutte, bhagavā aciravataṁ samaṇuddesaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte bhagavā aciravatam samaṇuddesam etat avoca
translated: When he had finished, the Blessed One said to him,

original: “‘taṁ kutettha, aggivessana, labbhā.
analyzed: tam kuta itthā aggivessana labbhā
translated: “‘Where is it possible, Aggivessana,🔽that what is to be known through renunciation, seen through renunciation, realized through renunciation,🔽experienced through renunciation,

original: Yaṁ taṁ nekkhammena ñātabbaṁ nekkhammena daṭṭhabbaṁ nekkhammena pattabbaṁ nekkhammena
analyzed: yam tam nekkhammena ñātabbam nekkhammena daṭṭhabbam nekkhammena pattabbam nekkhammena
translated: and directly known through renunciation by the Realized One—

original: sacchikātabbaṁ taṁ vata jayaseno rājakumāro kāmamajjhe vasanto kāme paribhuñjanto
analyzed: sacchikātabbam tam vata jayasenaḥ rāja kumāraḥ kāma majjhe vasantaḥ kāme paribhuñjantaḥ
translated: that Prince Jāyasena, living in the midst of sensual pleasures, enjoying sensual pleasures,

original: kāmavitakkehi khajjamāno kāmapariḷāhena pariḍayhamāno kāmapariyesanāya ussuko ñassati
analyzed: kāma vitakkehi khajjamānaḥ kāma pariḷāhena pariḍayhamānaḥ kāma pariyesanāya ussukaḥ ñassati
translated: He will not know, see, or realize it.

original: vā dakkhati vā sacchi vā karissatī’ti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: vā dakkhati vā sacchi vā karissati iti na etat ṭhānam vijjati
translated: It’s impossible for him to know, see, or realize it.”

original: Seyyathāpissu, aggivessana, dve hatthidammā vā assadammā vā godammā vā sudantā suvinītā, dve hatthidammā vā assadammā vā godammā vā adantā avinītā.
analyzed: seyyathā api su aggivessana dve hatthi dammā vā assa dammā vā go dammā vā su dantā su vinītā dve hatthi dammā vā assa dammā vā go dammā vā adantā avinītā
translated: “Suppose, Aggivessana, there were two tamed and well-bred elephants,

original: Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, aggivessana,
analyzed: tam kim maññasi aggivessana
translated: What do you think, Aggivessana?

original: ye te dve hatthidammā vā assadammā vā godammā vā sudantā suvinītā, api nu te dantāva dantakāraṇaṁ gaccheyyuṁ, dantāva dantabhūmiṁ sampāpuṇeyyun”ti?
analyzed: ye te dve hatthi dammā vā assa dammā vā go dammā vā su dantā su vinītā api nu te dantā ava danta kāraṇam gaccheyyu dantā ava danta bhūmim sampāpuṇeyyuḥ iti
translated: Would those two tamed and well-bred elephants go to the place where elephants are tamed and well-bred?”

original: “Evaṁ, bhante”.
analyzed: eva bhante
translated: “Yes, sir.”

original: “Ye pana te dve hatthidammā vā assadammā vā godammā vā adantā avinītā, api nu te🔽adantāva dantakāraṇaṁ gaccheyyuṁ, adantāva dantabhūmiṁ sampāpuṇeyyuṁ, seyyathāpi
analyzed: ye pana te dve hatthi dammāḥ vā assa dammāḥ vā go dammāḥ vā a dantāḥ a vinītāḥ api nu te 🔽a dantāḥ ava danta kāraṇam gaccheyyu a dantāḥ ava danta bhūmim sampāpuṇeyyu sā iyyathā api
translated: “But would those two untamed and unbroken elephants🔽go to the place where elephants are tamed and well-bred?”

original: te dve hatthidammā vā assadammā vā godammā vā sudantā suvinītā”ti?
analyzed: te dve hatthi dammā vā assa dammā vā go dammā vā su dantā su vinītā ati
translated: Are those two well-trained and disciplined in the training of elephants, horses, and bulls?”

original: “No hetaṁ, bhante”.
analyzed: naḥ heta bhante
translated: “No, venerable sir.”

original: “Evameva kho, aggivessana, ‘yaṁ taṁ nekkhammena ñātabbaṁ nekkhammena daṭṭhabbaṁ nekkhammena🔽pattabbaṁ nekkhammena sacchikātabbaṁ taṁ vata jayaseno rājakumāro kāmamajjhe vasanto
analyzed: evam eva kho aggivessana yam tam nekkhammena ñātabbam nekkhammena daṭṭhabbam nekkhammena  pattabbam nekkhammena sacchikātabbam tam vata jayasenaḥ rāja kumāraḥ kāma majjhe vasantaḥ
translated: “So too, Aggivessana, it is not possible that Prince Jayasena, living in a home crowded with children,🔽enjoying sensual pleasures, devouring the food of hell, burning with the fever of sensual pleasures,

original: kāme paribhuñjanto kāmavitakkehi khajjamāno kāmapariḷāhena pariḍayhamāno kāmapariyesanāya
analyzed: kāme paribhuñjantaḥ kāma vitakkehi khajjamānaḥ kāma pariḷāhena pariḍayhamānaḥ kāma pariyesanāya
translated: being consumed by the search for sensual pleasures,

original: ussuko ñassati vā dakkhati vā sacchi vā karissatī’ti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: ussukaḥ ñassati vā dakkhati vā sacchi vā karissati iti na etat ṭhānam vijjati
translated: could know, see, or realize that which must be known through renunciation, seen through renunciation,🔽attained through renunciation, experienced through renunciation,🔽or realized through renunciation.

original: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, gāmassa vā nigamassa vā avidūre mahāpabbato.
analyzed: seyyathā api aggivessana gāmassa vā nigamassa vā avidūre mahā pabbataḥ
translated: Suppose, Aggivessana, there were a great mountain not far from a village or town,

original: Tamenaṁ dve sahāyakā tamhā gāmā vā nigamā vā nikkhamitvā hatthavilaṅghakena yena
analyzed: tam enam dve sahāyakā tamhā gāmā vā nigamā vā nikkhamitvā hattha vilaṅghakena yena
translated: and two friends set out from that village or town to go to the mountain.

original: so pabbato tenupasaṅkameyyuṁ; upasaṅkamitvā eko sahāyako heṭṭhā pabbatapāde tiṭṭheyya,
analyzed: saḥ pabbataḥ tena upasaṅkameyyu upasaṅkamitvā ekaḥ sahāyakaḥ heṭṭhā pabbata pāde tiṭṭheyya
translated: After they had gone a little way, the first friend would sit down on the ground,

original: eko sahāyako uparipabbataṁ āroheyya.
analyzed: ekaḥ sahāyakaḥ upari pabbatam āroheyya
translated: One of them would climb up to the top of the mountain.

original: Tamenaṁ heṭṭhā pabbatapāde ṭhito sahāyako uparipabbate ṭhitaṁ sahāyakaṁ evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: tam enam heṭṭhā pabbata pāde ṭhitaḥ sahāyakaḥ upari pabbate ṭhitam sahāyakam evam vadeyya
translated: Standing there, he would say to his friend standing at the foot of the mountain,

original: ‘yaṁ, samma, kiṁ tvaṁ passasi uparipabbate ṭhito’ti?🔽So evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: ya samma kim tvam passasi upari pabbate ṭhito ti  saḥ u evam vadeyya
translated: ‘What do you see, friend, standing at the foot of the mountain?’

original: ‘passāmi kho ahaṁ, samma, uparipabbate ṭhito ārāmarāmaṇeyyakaṁ vanarāmaṇeyyakaṁ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṁ pokkharaṇīrāmaṇeyyakan’ti.🔽So evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: passāmi kho aha samma upari pabbate ṭhitaḥ ārāma rāmaṇeyyakam vana rāmaṇeyyakam bhūmi rāmaṇeyyakam pokkharaṇī rāmaṇeyyakanti  saḥ u evam vadeyya
translated: ‘I see the pleasant parks, groves, meadows, and ponds.’

original: ‘aṭṭhānaṁ kho etaṁ, samma, anavakāso yaṁ tvaṁ uparipabbate ṭhito passeyyāsi ārāmarāmaṇeyyakaṁ vanarāmaṇeyyakaṁ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṁ pokkharaṇīrāmaṇeyyakan’ti.
analyzed: aṭṭhānam kho eta samma anavakāsaḥ yam tvam upari pabbate ṭhitaḥ passeyyāsi ārāma rāmaṇeyyakam vana rāmaṇeyyakam bhūmi rāmaṇeyyakam pokkharaṇī rāmaṇeyyakam ti
translated: ‘It’s impossible, friend, it cannot happen that you, standing at the foot of the mountain, would see the pleasant parks, groves, meadows, and ponds.’

original: Tamenaṁ uparipabbate ṭhito sahāyako heṭṭhimapabbatapādaṁ orohitvā taṁ sahāyakaṁ bāhāyaṁ gahetvā uparipabbataṁ āropetvā muhuttaṁ assāsetvā evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: tam enam upari pabbate ṭhitaḥ sahāyakaḥ heṭṭhima pabbata pādam orohitvā tam sahāyakam bāhāyam gahetvā upari pabbatam āropetvā muhuttam assāsetvā evam vadeyya
translated: Then the friend standing at the top of the mountain would climb down, take his friend by the arm, and bring him up to the top of the mountain. After a short rest, he would say,

original: ‘yaṁ, samma, kiṁ tvaṁ passasi uparipabbate ṭhito’ti?
analyzed: ya samma kim tvam passasi upari pabbate ṭhito ti
translated: ‘What do you see, friend, standing at the top of the mountain?’

original: So evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: saḥ u evam vadeyya
translated: He might say:

original: ‘passāmi kho ahaṁ, samma, uparipabbate ṭhito ārāmarāmaṇeyyakaṁ vanarāmaṇeyyakaṁ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṁ pokkharaṇīrāmaṇeyyakan’ti.
analyzed: passāmi kho aha samma upari pabbate ṭhitaḥ ārāma rāmaṇeyyakam vana rāmaṇeyyakam bhūmi rāmaṇeyyakam pokkharaṇī rāmaṇeyyakanti
translated: ‘I see delightful parks, delightful forests, delightful meadows, and delightful ponds.’

original: So evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: saḥ u evam vadeyya
translated: He might say:

original: ‘idāneva kho te, samma, bhāsitaṁ—mayaṁ evaṁ ājānāma—
analyzed: idānā iva kho te samma bhāsita mayam evam ājānāma
translated: ‘Just now you said that, and we understood you like this.

original: aṭṭhānaṁ kho etaṁ samma, anavakāso yaṁ tvaṁ uparipabbate ṭhito passeyyāsi ārāmarāmaṇeyyakaṁ vanarāmaṇeyyakaṁ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṁ pokkharaṇīrāmaṇeyyakan’ti.
analyzed: aṭṭhānam kho etam samma anavakāsaḥ yam tvam upari pabbate ṭhitaḥ passeyyāsi ārāma rāmaṇeyyakam vana rāmaṇeyyakam bhūmi rāmaṇeyyakam pokkharaṇī rāmaṇeyyakam ti
translated: But it’s impossible that you could see all that from the top of the mountain.’

original: Idāneva ca pana te bhāsitaṁ mayaṁ evaṁ ājānāma:
analyzed: idānā iva ca pana te bhāsitam mayam evam ājānāma
translated: But you just said:

original: ‘passāmi kho ahaṁ, samma, uparipabbate ṭhito ārāmarāmaṇeyyakaṁ vanarāmaṇeyyakaṁ bhūmirāmaṇeyyakaṁ pokkharaṇīrāmaṇeyyakan’ti.
analyzed: passāmi kho aha samma upari pabbate ṭhitaḥ ārāma rāmaṇeyyakam vana rāmaṇeyyakam bhūmi rāmaṇeyyakam pokkharaṇī rāmaṇeyyakanti
translated: ‘I see delightful parks, delightful forests, delightful meadows, and delightful ponds.’

original: So evaṁ vadeyya:
analyzed: saḥ u evam vadeyya
translated: He might say:

analyzed: tathā hi pana āha samme iminā mahatā pabbatena āvutaḥ daṭṭheyyam na addasanti
translated: ‘Because I’m hidden by this great mountain, I can’t see what I should see.’

original: Ato mahantatarena, aggivessana, ‘avijjākhandhena jayaseno rājakumāro āvuto nivuto ophuṭo pariyonaddho.🔽So vata yaṁ taṁ nekkhammena ñātabbaṁ nekkhammena daṭṭhabbaṁ nekkhammena pattabbaṁ🔽nekkhammena sacchikātabbaṁ taṁ vata jayaseno rājakumāro kāmamajjhe vasanto kāme paribhuñjanto🔽kāmavitakkehi khajjamāno kāmapariḷāhena pariḍayhamāno kāmapariyesanāya ussuko ñassati
analyzed: atas mahantatarena aggivessana avijjā khandhena jayasenaḥ rāja kumāraḥ āvutaḥ nivutaḥ ophuṭaḥ pariyonaddhaḥ  saḥ vata yam tam nekkhammena ñātabbam nekkhammena daṭṭhabbam nekkhammena pattabba  nekkhammena sacchikātabbam tam vata jayasenaḥ rāja kumāraḥ kāma majjhe vasantaḥ kāme paribhuñjantaḥ  kāma vitakkehi khajjamānaḥ kāma pariḷāhena pariḍayhamānaḥ kāma pariyesanāya ussukaḥ ñassati
translated: “Then, Aggivessana, Prince Jayasena is even more enveloped, enclosed, and obstructed by the mass of ignorance than Prince Jayasena’s father, King Udena.

original: vā dakkhati vā sacchi vā karissatī’ti—netaṁ ṭhānaṁ vijjati.
analyzed: vā dakkhati vā sacchi vā karissati iti na etat ṭhānam vijjati
translated: “It is not possible, Aggivessana, that Prince Jayasena, living in the midst of sensual pleasures, enjoying sensual pleasures, burning with sensual pleasures, being consumed by sensual pleasures, being inflamed by sensual pleasures, being heated by sensual pleasures, should know, see, or realise that which must be known through renunciation, seen through renunciation, attained through renunciation,🔽realized through renunciation.🔽If these two similes had occurred to Prince Jayasena, it would not be surprising if Prince Jayasena had become confident in me, and, being confident, had shown me confidence.”

original: Sace kho taṁ, aggivessana, jayasenassa rājakumārassa imā dve upamā paṭibhāyeyyuṁ, anacchariyaṁ te jayaseno rājakumāro pasīdeyya, pasanno ca te pasannākāraṁ kareyyā”ti.
analyzed: sace kho te aggivessana jayasenassa rāja kumārassa imāḥ dve upamāḥ paṭibhāyeyyu anacchariyam te jayasenaḥ rāja kumāraḥ pasīdeyya pasannaḥ ca te pasanna ākāram kareyya ati
translated: If these two similes had occurred to you, it would not have been surprising that Prince Jayasena would have gained confidence in you, and that, gaining confidence, he would have shown his confidence to you.”

original: “Kuto pana maṁ, bhante, jayasenassa rājakumārassa imā dve upamā paṭibhāyissanti anacchariyā pubbe assutapubbā, seyyathāpi bhagavantan”ti?🔽“Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto nāgavanikaṁ āmanteti:
analyzed: kutas pana ma bhante jayasenassa rāja kumārassa imāḥ dve upamāḥ paṭibhāyissanti an acchariyā pubbe a suta pubbā seyyathā api bhagavantam ti  sa iyyathā api aggivessana rājā khattiyaḥ muddhāvasittaḥ nāga vanikam āmanteti
translated: “But where, venerable sir, could I find such a simile as that, which is so very simple and yet so very profound?”🔽“Suppose, Aggivessana, a head-anointed noble king had a tusker elephant with tusks as long as chariot-poles, of great size and strength, endowed with the supreme state of being a fully grown elephant.

original: ‘ehi tvaṁ, samma nāgavanika, rañño nāgaṁ abhiruhitvā nāgavanaṁ pavisitvā āraññakaṁ nāgaṁ atipassitvā rañño nāgassa gīvāyaṁ upanibandhāhī’ti.
analyzed: ehi tva samma nāgavanika raññaḥ nāgam abhiruhitvā nāga vanam pavisitvā āraññakam nāgam atipassitvā raññaḥ nāgassa gīvāyam upanibandhāhi iti
translated: He would tell a mahout: ‘Good mahout, mount this tusker elephant and go out to the elephant wood.🔽When you have seen a wild elephant there, catch hold of his tuft of hair at the nape of the neck.’

original: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, aggivessana, nāgavaniko rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa paṭissutvā🔽rañño nāgaṁ abhiruhitvā nāgavanaṁ pavisitvā āraññakaṁ nāgaṁ atipassitvā rañño nāgassa🔽gīvāyaṁ upanibandhati.
analyzed: eva deva ati kho aggivessana nāgavanikaḥ raññaḥ khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa paṭissutvā  raññaḥ nāgam abhiruhitvā nāgavanam pavisitvā āraññakam nāgam atipassitvā raññaḥ nāgassa  gīvā ayam upanibandhati
translated: ‘Yes, sire,’ the mahout would reply, and he would mount the tusker elephant and go out to the elephant wood.🔽When he saw a wild elephant there, he would catch hold of its tuft of hair at the nape of the neck.

original: Tamenaṁ rañño nāgo abbhokāsaṁ nīharati.
analyzed: tam enam raññaḥ nāgaḥ abbhokāsam nīharati
translated: The tusker elephant would drag him out into the open.

original: Ettāvatā kho, aggivessana, āraññako nāgo abbhokāsaṁ gato hoti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho aggivessanaḥ āraññakaḥ nāgaḥ abbhokāsam gataḥ hoti
translated: To this extent, Aggivessana, the wild elephant has gone out into the open.

original: Etthagedhā hi, aggivessana, āraññakā nāgā yadidaṁ—nāgavanaṁ.
analyzed: etthagedhāḥ hi aggivessana āraññakāḥ nāgāḥ
translated: For that is where wild elephants live.

original: Tamenaṁ nāgavaniko rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa ārocesi:
analyzed: tam enam nāgavanikaḥ raññaḥ khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa ārocesi
translated: The elephant tamer then informed the king:

original: ‘abbhokāsagato kho, deva, āraññako nāgo’ti.
analyzed: abbhokāsa gataḥ kho deva āraññakaḥ nāgaḥ ti
translated: ‘Your majesty, the wild elephant has come out into the open.’

original: Atha kho aggivessana, tamenaṁ rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto hatthidamakaṁ āmantesi:
analyzed: atha kho aggivessana tam enam rājā khattiyaḥ muddhāvasittaḥ hatthidamakam āmantesi
translated: Then the king, having ordered the elephant tamer to tame the wild elephant,

original: ‘ehi tvaṁ, samma hatthidamaka, āraññakaṁ nāgaṁ damayāhi āraññakānañceva sīlānaṁ abhinimmadanāya
analyzed: ehi tva samma hatthidamaka āraññakam nāgam damayāhi āraññakānam ca iva sīlānam abhinimmadanāya
translated: said: ‘Come, my good elephant tamer, tame the wild elephant,🔽to make him give up the habits of a wild elephant,

original: āraññakānañceva sarasaṅkappānaṁ abhinimmadanāya āraññakānañceva darathakilamathapariḷāhānaṁ
analyzed: āraññakānam ca iva sara saṅkappānam abhinimmadanāya āraññakānam ca iva daratha kilamatha pariḷāhānam
translated: to make him give up the thoughts, resolves, wishes, and intentions of a wild elephant,🔽to make him give up the weariness, troubles, and feverish burning of a wild elephant,

original: abhinimmadanāya gāmante abhiramāpanāya manussakantesu sīlesu samādapanāyā’ti.
analyzed: abhinimmadanāya gāmante abhiramāpanāya manussa kantesu sīlesu samādapanāya ati
translated: and to make him delight in the village life and take up the habits of a human being.’

original: ‘Evaṁ, devā’ti kho, aggivessana, hatthidamako rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa
analyzed: eva deva ati kho aggivessana hatthidamakaḥ raññaḥ khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa
translated: ‘Yes, your majesty,’ the elephant tamer replied.

original: paṭissutvā mahantaṁ thambhaṁ pathaviyaṁ nikhaṇitvā āraññakassa nāgassa gīvāyaṁ upanibandhati
analyzed: paṭissutvā mahantam thambham pathaviyam nikhaṇitvā āraññakassa nāgassa gīvāyam upanibandhati
translated: He drove a great post into the ground and tied the wild elephant to it with a rope of plaited creeper,

original: āraññakānañceva sīlānaṁ abhinimmadanāya āraññakānañceva sarasaṅkappānaṁ abhinimmadanāya
analyzed: āraññakānam ca iva sīlānam abhinimmadanāya āraññakānam ca iva sara saṅkappānam abhinimmadanāya
translated: for the sake of the forest-dwelling monks’ abandoning of their forest-dwelling view,🔽for the sake of the forest-dwelling monks’ abandoning of their forest-dwelling thoughts,

original: āraññakānañceva darathakilamathapariḷāhānaṁ abhinimmadanāya gāmante abhiramāpanāya
analyzed: āraññakānam ca iva daratha kilamatha pariḷāhānam abhinimmadanāya gāmante abhiramāpanāya
translated: for the sake of the forest-dwelling monks’ abandoning of their forest-dwelling desires, for the sake of their delighting in the village,

original: manussakantesu sīlesu samādapanāya.
analyzed: manussa kantesu sīlesu samādapanāya
translated: for the sake of establishing them in the virtues dear to the noble ones.🔽Then the elephant tamer approaches him with speech that is polished,

original: Tamenaṁ hatthidamako yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpāhi vācāhi samudācarati.
analyzed: tam enam hatthidamakaḥ yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇa sukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahu jana kantā bahu jana manāpā tathārūpāhi vācāhi samudācarati
translated: pleasing to the ear, and loveable, that enters the mind and is agreeable, urbane, and endearing to the multitude.

original: Yato kho, aggivessana, āraññako nāgo hatthidamakassa yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā
analyzed: yatas kho aggivessanaḥ āraññakaḥ nāgaḥ hatthidamakassa yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇa sukhā pemanīyā
translated: When the forest-dwelling elephant approaches the elephant tamer with speech that is polished,🔽pleasing to the ear, and loveable,

original: hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpāhi vācāhi samudācariyamāno
analyzed: hadayaṅgamā porī bahu jana kantā bahu jana manāpā tathārūpāhi vācāhi samudācariyamānaḥ
translated: that enters the mind and is agreeable, urbane, and endearing to the multitude,

original: sussūsati, sotaṁ odahati, aññā cittaṁ upaṭṭhāpeti;
analyzed: sussūsati sotam odahati aññā cittam upaṭṭhāpeti
translated: and listens, gives ear, and engages the mind,

original: tamenaṁ hatthidamako uttari tiṇaghāsodakaṁ anuppavecchati.
analyzed: tam enam hatthi damakaḥ uttari tiṇa ghāsa udakam anuppavecchati
translated: then the elephant tamer provides him with grass and water.

original: Yato kho, aggivessana, āraññako nāgo hatthidamakassa tiṇaghāsodakaṁ paṭiggaṇhāti, tatra hatthidamakassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: yatas kho aggivessanaḥ āraññakaḥ nāgaḥ hatthi damakassa tiṇa ghāsa udakam paṭiggaṇhāti tatra hatthi damakassa evam hoti
translated: When the forest elephant accepts grass, water, and fodder from the elephant tamer, the elephant tamer thinks:

original: ‘jīvissati kho dāni āraññako nāgo’ti.
analyzed: jīvissati kho dāni āraññakaḥ nāgaḥ ti
translated: ‘The forest elephant will live.’

original: Tamenaṁ hatthidamako uttari kāraṇaṁ kāreti:
analyzed: tam enam hatthidamakaḥ uttari kāraṇam kāreti
translated: He then gives him further instructions:

original: ‘ādiya, bho, nikkhipa, bho’ti.
analyzed: ādiya bho nikkhipa bhoti
translated: ‘Take it! Put it down!’

original: Yato kho, aggivessana, āraññako nāgo hatthidamakassa ādānanikkhepe vacanakaro hoti ovādappaṭikaro, tamenaṁ hatthidamako uttari kāraṇaṁ kāreti:
analyzed: yatas kho aggivessana āraññakaḥ nāgaḥ hatthi damakassa ādāna nikkhepe vacana karaḥ hoti ovāda ppaṭikaraḥ tam enam hatthi damakaḥ uttari kāraṇam kāreti
translated: When the forest elephant obeys the instructions to take and put down, the elephant tamer gives him further instructions:

original: ‘abhikkama, bho, paṭikkama, bho’ti.
analyzed: abhikkama bho paṭikkama bhoti
translated: ‘Go forward! Go back!’

original: Yato kho, aggivessana, āraññako nāgo hatthidamakassa abhikkamapaṭikkamavacanakaro hoti ovādappaṭikaro, tamenaṁ hatthidamako uttari kāraṇaṁ kāreti:
analyzed: yatas kho aggivessana āraññakaḥ nāgaḥ hatthi damakassa abhikkama paṭikkama vacana karaḥ hoti ovāda ppaṭikaraḥ tam enam hatthi damakaḥ uttari kāraṇam kāreti
translated: When the forest elephant obeys the instructions to go forward and go back, the elephant tamer gives him further instructions:

original: ‘uṭṭhaha, bho, nisīda, bho’ti.
analyzed: uṭṭhaha bho nisīda bho ti
translated: ‘Get up! Sit down!’

original: Yato kho, aggivessana, āraññako nāgo hatthidamakassa uṭṭhānanisajjāya vacanakaro
analyzed: yatas kho aggivessanaḥ āraññakaḥ nāgaḥ hatthi damakassa uṭṭhāna nisajjāya vacana karaḥ
translated: When the forest elephant obeys the instructions to get up and sit down,

original: hoti ovādappaṭikaro, tamenaṁ hatthidamako uttari āneñjaṁ nāma kāraṇaṁ kāreti, mahantassa
analyzed: hoti ovāda paṭikaraḥ tam enam hatthidamakaḥ uttari āneñjam nāma kāraṇam kāreti mahantassa
translated: and the elephant tamer makes him do the further training called ‘unwavering’,

original: phalakaṁ soṇḍāya upanibandhati, tomarahattho ca puriso uparigīvāya nisinno hoti,🔽samantato ca tomarahatthā purisā parivāretvā ṭhitā honti, hatthidamako ca dīghatomarayaṭṭhiṁ
analyzed: phalakam soṇḍāya upanibandhati tomara hattho ca purisaḥ uparigīvāya nisinno hoti  samantataḥ ca tomara hatthā purisā parivāretvā ṭhitāḥ honti hatthi damakaḥ ca dīghatomara yaṭṭhi
translated: he ties a large plank to his trunk, and a man armed with a spear sits on his neck,

original: gahetvā purato ṭhito hoti.
analyzed: gahetvā puratas ṭhitaḥ hoti
translated: and men armed with spears stand all around him, and the elephant tamer stands in front of him holding a long spear.

original: So āneñjaṁ kāraṇaṁ kāriyamāno neva purime pāde copeti na pacchime pāde copeti, na🔽purimakāyaṁ copeti na pacchimakāyaṁ copeti, na sīsaṁ copeti, na kaṇṇe copeti, na
analyzed: saḥ āneñjam kāraṇam kāriyamānaḥ na iva purime pāde ca upeti na pacchime pāde ca upeti na  purima kāyam ca upeti na pacchima kāyam ca upeti na sīsam ca upeti na kaṇṇe ca upeti na
translated: When he is being made to do the training called ‘unwavering’, he does not step on his front feet or his back feet,🔽he does not step with his front body or his back body, he does not step with his head or his ears,

original: dante copeti, na naṅguṭṭhaṁ copeti, na soṇḍaṁ copeti.🔽So hoti āraññako nāgo khamo sattippahārānaṁ asippahārānaṁ usuppahārānaṁ sarapattappahārānaṁ
analyzed: dante ca upeti na naṅguṭṭham ca upeti na soṇḍam ca upeti  saḥ hoti āraññakaḥ nāgaḥ khamaḥ satti ppahārānam asi ppahārānam usu ppahārānam sara patta ppahārānam
translated: he does not step with his tusks or his tail or his trunk.🔽He is a forest elephant, able to endure blows from spears, swords, arrows, and scimitars,

original: bheripaṇavavaṁsasaṅkhaḍiṇḍimaninnādasaddānaṁ sabbavaṅkadosanihitaninnītakasāvo rājāraho
analyzed: bheri paṇava vasa saṅkha ḍiṇḍima ninnāda saddānam sabba vaṅka dosa nihita ninnīta kasāvaḥ
translated: and the sounds of drums, kettledrums, conches, and cymbals. He has removed all crookedness, faults, and impurities, and is worthy of the king,

original: rājabhoggo rañño aṅganteva saṅkhaṁ gacchati.🔽Evameva kho, aggivessana, idha tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
analyzed: rāja bhoggaḥ raññaḥ aṅgantā iva saṅkham gacchati  evam eva kho aggivessana idha tathāgataḥ loke uppajjati araham sammāsambuddhaḥ vijjā caraṇa sampannaḥ sugataḥ loka vidū anuttaraḥ purisa damma sārathi satthā deva manussānam buddhaḥ bhagavā
translated: the king’s enjoyment is reckoned as the king’s property.🔽“So too, Aggivessana, a Tathagata appears in the world, accomplished, fully enlightened…

original: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
analyzed: saḥ imam lokam sa devakam sa mārakam sa brahmakam sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇim pajam sa deva manussam sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti
translated: He reveals this world—with its devas, Mara, and Brahma, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its devas and hum ans—having comprehended it through his own mind.

original: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
analyzed: saḥ dhammam deseti ādi kalyāṇam majjhe kalyāṇam pariyosāna kalyāṇam sa attham sa byañjana kevala paripuṇṇam parisuddham brahmacariyam pakāseti
translated: He teaches the Dhamma that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with the right meaning and phrasing, and he reveals a holy life that is utterly perfect and pure.

original: Taṁ dhammaṁ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṁ vā kule paccājāto.
analyzed: tam dhammam suṇāti gahapati vā gahapati putto vā aññatarasmim vā kule paccājātaḥ
translated: A householder or householder’s son or one born in some other clan hears that Dhamma.

original: So taṁ dhammaṁ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṁ paṭilabhati.
analyzed: saḥ tam dhammam sutvā tathāgate saddham paṭilabhati
translated: On hearing the Dhamma he acquires faith in the Tathagata.

original: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: saḥ tena saddhā paṭilābhena samannāgataḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: Endowed with that faith, he considers thus:

original: ‘sambādho gharāvāso rajāpatho, abbhokāso pabbajjā.
analyzed: sambādhaḥ gharāvāsaḥ rajāpathaḥ abbhokāsaḥ pabbajjā
translated: ‘Living in a home is constricting, a dusty path.

original: Nayidaṁ sukaraṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṁ ekantaparisuddhaṁ saṅkhalikhitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ carituṁ.
analyzed: na idam sukaram agāram ajjhāvasatā ekanta paripuṇṇam ekanta parisuddham saṅkha likhitam brahmacariyam caritu
translated: It’s not easy for one who lives at home to live the spiritual life totally perfect & pure as a polished conch.

original: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.🔽So aparena samayena appaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya🔽appaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya kesamassuṁ ohāretvā
analyzed: yat nūna aham kesa massuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni a chādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajeyyanti  so aparena samayena appam vā bhogakkhandham pahāya mahantam vā bhogakkhandham pahāya  appam vā ñāti parivaṭṭam pahāya mahantam vā ñāti parivaṭṭam pahāya kesa massuṃ ohāretvā
translated: Why don’t I shave my head & beard, put on the ocher robes, and go forth from the home life into homelessness?’

original: kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.
analyzed: kāsāyāni vatthāni a chādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajati
translated: “Then, after some time, he abandons a small or a great fortune, abandons a small or a great circle of relatives, shaves his head & beard, puts on the ocher robes, and goes forth from the home life into homelessness.

original: Ettāvatā kho, aggivessana, ariyasāvako abbhokāsagato hoti.
analyzed: ettāvatā kho aggivessana ariya sāvakaḥ abbhokāsa gataḥ hoti
translated: To this extent, Aggivessana, a disciple of the noble ones is one who goes into homelessness.

original: Etthagedhā hi, aggivessana, devamanussā yadidaṁ—pañca kāmaguṇā.
analyzed: etthagedhāḥ hi aggivessana deva manussāḥ kāma guṇā
translated: For it is to this extent that gods & human beings find satisfaction in the five strings of sensuality.

original: Tamenaṁ tathāgato uttariṁ vineti:
analyzed: tam enam tathāgataḥ uttarim vinā iti
translated: “The Tathāgata then disciplines him further:

original: ‘ehi tvaṁ, bhikkhu, sīlavā hohi, pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharāhi ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhassu sikkhāpadesū’ti.
analyzed: ehi tva bhikkhu sīlavā hohi pātimokkha savara savutaḥ viharāhi ācāra gocara sampannaḥ aṇumattesu vajjesu bhaya dassāvī samādāya sikkhassu sikkhāpadesu uti
translated: ‘Come, monk, be virtuous, restrained with the restraint of the rules, live the holy life, having undertaken the training rules, seeing danger in the slightest fault, training in them.’

original: Yato kho, aggivessana, ariyasāvako sīlavā hoti, pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati
analyzed: yatas kho aggivessana ariya sāvakaḥ sīlavā hoti pātimokkha savara savutaḥ viharati
translated: When a noble disciple is virtuous, restrained with the restraint of the rules,

original: ācāragocarasampanno aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu,
analyzed: ācāra gocara sampannaḥ aṇumattesu vajjesu bhaya dassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu
translated: living the holy life, having undertaken the training rules, seeing danger in the slightest fault, training in them,

original: tamenaṁ tathāgato uttariṁ vineti:
analyzed: tam enam tathāgataḥ uttarim vinā iti
translated: then the Realised One teaches him further:

original: ‘ehi tvaṁ, bhikkhu, indriyesu guttadvāro hohi, cakkhunā rūpaṁ disvā mā nimittaggāhī …pe…
analyzed: ehi tva bhikkhu indriyesu gutta dvāraḥ hohi cakkhunā rūpam disvā mā nimitta ggāhī pe
translated: ‘Come, monk, guard the doors of your sense faculties. On seeing a form with the eye, do not grasp at its signs and features.

original: (yathā gaṇakamoggallānasuttante, evaṁ vitthāretabbāni.)
analyzed: yathā gaṇaka moggallāna suttante evam vitthāretabbāni
translated: (This should be expanded as in the Discourse on the Wise and the Foolish.)🔽Having given up these five hindrances,

original: So ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetaso upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
analyzed: saḥ ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahāya cetasaḥ upakkilese paññāya dubbalīkaraṇe
translated: he abides in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, accompanied by directed thought and evaluation.

original: kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.🔽Vedanāsu …pe…
analyzed: kāye kāya anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa  vedanāsu pe
translated: He abides in the second absorption, which has internal confidence and unification of mind, is without directed thought, and has rapture and bliss born of concentration.

original: citte …
analyzed: citte
translated: He abides in the third absorption, which has neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings, and is accompanied by pure mindfulness and equanimity.

original: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.
analyzed: dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa
translated: He dwells contemplating (the nature of) things in (various) things, ardent, clearly comprehending, unified, with complete awareness, mindful, having removed covetousness and displeasure in regard to the world.🔽Just as, Aggivessana, a trainer of elephants, having taken a great elephant,

original: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, hatthidamako mahantaṁ thambhaṁ pathaviyaṁ nikhaṇitvā āraññakassa🔽nāgassa gīvāyaṁ upanibandhati āraññakānañceva sīlānaṁ abhinimmadanāya āraññakānañceva
analyzed: seyyathā api aggivessana hatthi damakaḥ mahantam thambham pathaviyam nikhaṇitvā āraññakassa  nāgassa gīvāyam upanibandhati āraññakānam ca iva sīlānam abhinimmadanāya āraññakānam ca iva
translated: after tying his neck to a strong post or pillar,

original: sarasaṅkappānaṁ abhinimmadanāya āraññakānañceva darathakilamathapariḷāhānaṁ abhinimmadanāya
analyzed: sara saṅkappānam abhinimmadanāya āraññakānam ca iva daratha kilamatha pariḷāhānam abhinimmadanāya
translated: in order to subdue his forest ways, in order to subdue his forest thoughts, in order to subdue his forest desires,

original: gāmante abhiramāpanāya manussakantesu sīlesu samādapanāya;
analyzed: gāmante abhiramāpanāya manussa kantesu sīlesu samādapanāya
translated: in order to make him delight in the town, in order to make him delight in human ways,

original: evameva kho, aggivessana, ariyasāvakassa ime cattāro satipaṭṭhānā cetaso upanibandhanā
analyzed: evam eva kho aggivessana ariya sāvakassa ime cattāro sati paṭṭhānā cetasaḥ upanibandhanā
translated: even so, Aggivessana, these four ways of attending to mindfulness are for a Noble Disciple a binding of the mind,

original: honti gehasitānañceva sīlānaṁ abhinimmadanāya gehasitānañceva sarasaṅkappānaṁ abhinimmadanāya
analyzed: honti geha sitānam ca iva sīlānam abhinimmadanāya geha sitānam ca iva sara saṅkappānam abhinimmadanāya
translated: in order to subdue the morality of the house life, in order to subdue the thoughts of the house life,

original: gehasitānañceva darathakilamathapariḷāhānaṁ abhinimmadanāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya.
analyzed: geha sitānam ca iva daratha kilamatha pariḷāhānam abhinimmadanāya ñāyassa adhigamāya nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya
translated: for the purpose of abandoning the various kinds of sensual desire and discontent that arise, for the purpose of attaining the right way, for the purpose of realizing Nibbāna.

original: Tamenaṁ tathāgato uttariṁ vineti:🔽‘ehi tvaṁ, bhikkhu, kāye kāyānupassī viharāhi, mā ca kāmūpasaṁhitaṁ vitakkaṁ vitakkesi.
analyzed: tam enam tathāgataḥ uttarim vinā iti  ehi tva bhikkhu kāye kāya anupassī viharāhi mā ca kāma upasahitam vitakkam vitakkesi
translated: The Tathāgata then disciplines him further:🔽‘Come, bhikkhu, abide contemplating the body as a body, but do not think thoughts connected with sensual desire.

original: Vedanāsu …🔽citte …
analyzed: vedanāsu  citte
translated: Abide contemplating feelings as feelings, but do not think thoughts connected with sensual desire.🔽Abide contemplating the mind as mind, but do not think thoughts connected with sensual desire.

original: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharāhi, mā ca kāmūpasaṁhitaṁ vitakkaṁ vitakkesī’ti.
analyzed: dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharāhi mā ca kāma upasahitam vitakkam vitakkesi iti
translated: Abide contemplating things as things, but do not think thoughts connected with sensual desire.’🔽Then, with the stilling of applied and sustained thought, he enters upon and abides in the second jhāna, which has internal confidence and unification of mind, is without applied thought, is filled with rapture and joy, and has a single area of radiance.

original: So vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ …🔽tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ …
analyzed: saḥ vitakka vicārānam vūpasamāḥ ajjhattam sampasādanam cetasaḥ eka udi bhāvam a vitakkam a vicāram samādhi jam pīti sukham dutiyam jhānam  tatiyam jhānam
translated: He emerges mindful from that attainment and enters upon and abides in the third jhāna…

original: catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: He emerges mindful from that attainment and enters upon and abides in the fourth jhāna…

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāmeti
translated: When his concentrated mind is thus purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the recollection of past lives.

original: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
analyzed: so aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati sa iyyathida ekam pi jātim dve pi jātiyaḥ pe iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati
translated: He recollects his manifold past lives, i.e. one birth, two five, ten fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand, many eons of cosmic contraction, many eons of cosmic expansion, many eons of cosmic contraction and expansion, ‘There I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity to pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose there. There too I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity to pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose here.’ Thus he recollects his manifold past lives in their modes and details.

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte sattānam cutūpapāta ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāmeti
translated: “When his concentrated mind is thus purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.

original: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
analyzed: so dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate pe yathā kamma upage satte pajānāti
translated: He sees beings passing away and re-appearing, inferior and superior, fair and ugly, happy and unhappy in their destiny. He understands how beings pass on according to their actions thus: ‘These worthy beings who were ill-conducted in body, speech, and mind, revilers of noble ones, wrong in their views, giving effect to wrong view, on the dissolution of the body, after death, have reappeared in a state of deprivation, in a bad destination, in perdition, even in hell.

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte āsavānam khaya ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāmeti
translated: “When his concentrated mind is thus purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the destruction of the taints.

original: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,
analyzed: saḥ idam dukkhan ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: He understands as it really is: ‘This is suffering’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the origin of suffering’;

original: ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti🔽yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti;
analyzed: ayam dukkha nirodho ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati  yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: he understands as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of suffering’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’

original: ‘ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,🔽‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti
analyzed: ime āsavāḥ ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti  ayam āsava nirodha uti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati
translated: He understands as it really is: ‘These are the taints’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the origin of the taints’;

original: yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: he understands as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of the taints’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.’

original: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati.
analyzed: tassa evam jānataḥ evam passataḥ kāma āsavā api cittam vimuccati bhava āsavā api cittam vimuccati avijjā āsavā api cittam vimuccati
translated: When he knows and sees thus, his mind is liberated from the taint of sensual desire, from the taint of being, and from the taint of ignorance.

original: Vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ hoti.
analyzed: vimuttasmin vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti
translated: When it is liberated there comes the knowledge: ‘It is liberated.’

original: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti
translated: He understands: ‘Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.’

original: So hoti bhikkhu khamo sītassa uṇhassa jighacchāya pipāsāya ḍaṁsamakasavātātapasarīsapasamphassānaṁ🔽duruttānaṁ durāgatānaṁ vacanapathānaṁ, uppannānaṁ sārīrikānaṁ vedanānaṁ dukkhānaṁ🔽tibbānaṁ kharānaṁ kaṭukānaṁ asātānaṁ amanāpānaṁ pāṇaharānaṁ adhivāsakajātiko hoti
analyzed: so hoti bhikkhu khamo sītassa uṇhassa jighacchāya pipāsāya  duruttānam durāgatānam vacana pathānam uppannānam sārīrikānam vedanānam dukkhānam  tibbānam kharānam kaṭukānam asātānam amanāpānam pāṇa harānam adhivāsaka jātikaḥ hoti
translated: He is able to endure cold and heat, hunger and thirst,🔽and contact with flies, mosquitoes, wind, the burning sun, and serpents;🔽and he is able to bear ill-spoken, unwelcome words and bodily feelings that are painful, racking, sharp, piercing, disagreeable, distressing, and menacing to life.

original: sabbarāgadosamohanihitaninnītakasāvo āhuneyyo pāhuneyyo dakkhiṇeyyo añjalikaraṇīyo anuttaraṁ puññakkhettaṁ lokassa.🔽Mahallako cepi, aggivessana, rañño nāgo adanto avinīto kālaṁ karoti, ‘adantamaraṇaṁ mahallako rañño nāgo kālaṅkato’tveva saṅkhaṁ gacchati;🔽majjhimo cepi, aggivessana, rañño nāgo.
analyzed: sabba rāga dosa moha nihita ninnīta kasāvaḥ āhuneyyo pāhuneyyaḥ dakkhiṇeyyaḥ añjali karaṇīyaḥ anuttaram puññakkhettam lokassa  mahallakaḥ cepi aggivessana raññaḥ nāgaḥ a dantaḥ a vinītaḥ kālam karoti a danta maraṇam mahallakaḥ raññaḥ nāgaḥ saṅkham gacchati  majjhimaḥ cepi aggivessana raññaḥ nāgaḥ
translated: He is one who has abandoned the corruptions, cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them so that they are no longer subject to future arising. He is worthy of offerings, of hospitality, of gifts, and of reverential salutation; he is an unsurpassed field of merit for the world.🔽If a king’s elephant, though huge, is untrained and undisciplined, when it dies it is reckoned as the death of an untrained elephant.🔽If a king’s elephant, though middle-sized, is untrained and undisciplined, when it dies it is reckoned as the death of an untrained elephant.

original: Daharo cepi, aggivessana, rañño nāgo adanto avinīto kālaṁ karoti, ‘adantamaraṇaṁ daharo rañño nāgo kālaṅkato’tveva saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
analyzed: daharaḥ cepi aggivessana raññaḥ nāgaḥ adantaḥ avinīto kālam karoti adanta maraṇam daharaḥ raññaḥ nāgaḥ saṅkham gacchati
translated: If a king’s elephant, though young, is untrained and undisciplined, when it dies it is reckoned as the death of an untrained elephant.

original: evameva kho, aggivessana, thero cepi bhikkhu akhīṇāsavo kālaṁ karoti, ‘adantamaraṇaṁ thero bhikkhu kālaṅkato’tveva saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
analyzed: evam eva kho aggivessana theraḥ ce pi bhikkhu akhīṇa āsavaḥ kālam karoti adantamaraṇam theraḥ bhikkhu saṅkham gacchati
translated: In the same way, Aggivessana, if an elder bhikkhu who has not abandoned the taints dies, it is said of him: ‘An elder bhikkhu has died, untamed in his body, speech, and mind, untamed in the three doors.’

original: majjhimo cepi, aggivessana, bhikkhu.
analyzed: majjhimaḥ cepi aggivessana bhikkhu
translated: If a bhikkhu of middle standing…

original: Navo cepi, aggivessana, bhikkhu akhīṇāsavo kālaṁ karoti, ‘adantamaraṇaṁ navo bhikkhu kālaṅkato’tveva saṅkhaṁ gacchati.
analyzed: navaḥ ce pi aggivessana bhikkhu a khīṇa āsavaḥ kālam karoti adanta maraṇam navaḥ bhikkhu saṅkham gacchati
translated: If a junior bhikkhu who has not abandoned the taints dies, it is said of him: ‘A junior bhikkhu has died, untamed in his body, speech, and mind, untamed in the three doors.’

original: Mahallako cepi, aggivessana, rañño nāgo sudanto suvinīto kālaṁ karoti, ‘dantamaraṇaṁ mahallako rañño nāgo kālaṅkato’tveva saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
analyzed: mahallakaḥ cepi aggivessana raññaḥ nāgaḥ su dantaḥ su vinīto kālam karoti danta maraṇam mahallakaḥ raññaḥ nāgaḥ saṅkham gacchati
translated: If a king’s tusker elephant who is well tamed and well disciplined dies, it is said of him: ‘A king’s tusker elephant has died, tamed in body, tamed in speech, tamed in mind, tamed in the three doors.’

original: majjhimo cepi, aggivessana, rañño nāgo …🔽daharo cepi, aggivessana, rañño nāgo sudanto suvinīto kālaṁ karoti, ‘dantamaraṇaṁ daharo rañño nāgo kālaṅkato’tveva saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
analyzed: majjhimaḥ cepi aggivessana raññaḥ nāgaḥ 🔽daharaḥ cepi aggivessana raññaḥ nāgaḥ su danto su vinīto kālam karoti danta maraṇam daharaḥ raññaḥ nāgaḥ saṅkham gacchati
translated: If a king’s tusker elephant of middle standing…🔽If a young tusker elephant who is well tamed and well disciplined dies, it is said of him: ‘A young tusker elephant has died, tamed in body, tamed in speech, tamed in mind, tamed in the three doors.’

original: evameva kho, aggivessana, thero cepi bhikkhu khīṇāsavo kālaṁ karoti, ‘dantamaraṇaṁ thero bhikkhu kālaṅkato’tveva saṅkhaṁ gacchati;
analyzed: evam eva kho aggivessana theraḥ ce pi bhikkhu khīṇa āsavaḥ kālam karoti dantamaraṇam theraḥ bhikkhu saṅkham gacchati
translated: So too, Aggivessana, if an elder bhikkhu who is an arahant, whose taints are destroyed, whose life of purity is fulfilled, who has done what had to be done, laid down the burden, reached his own goal, utterly destroyed the fetters of existence, and is completely liberated through final knowledge, dies, it is said of him: ‘An elder bhikkhu has died.

original: majjhimo cepi, aggivessana, bhikkhu.
analyzed: majjhimaḥ cepi aggivessana bhikkhu
translated: So too, Aggivessana, if a bhikkhu of middle standing…

original: Navo cepi, aggivessana, bhikkhu khīṇāsavo kālaṁ karoti, ‘dantamaraṇaṁ navo bhikkhu kālaṅkato’tveva saṅkhaṁ gacchatī”ti.
analyzed: navaḥ ce pi aggivessana bhikkhu khīṇa āsavaḥ kālam karoti danta maraṇam navaḥ bhikkhu saṅkham gacchati iti
translated: So too, Aggivessana, if a bhikkhu of recent admission who is an arahant, whose taints are destroyed, whose life of purity is fulfilled, who has done what had to be done, laid down the burden, reached his own goal, utterly destroyed the fetters of existence, and is completely liberated through final knowledge, dies, it is said of him: ‘A bhikkhu of recent admission has died. He was an arahant whose taints were destroyed.’“

original: Idamavoca bhagavā.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān
translated: This is what the Blessed One said.

original: Attamano aciravato samaṇuddeso bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.
analyzed: atta manaḥ aciravataḥ samaṇuddesaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandi iti
translated: And the novice attendant Aciravata was satisfied and delighted in the Blessed One’s words.

original: Dantabhūmisuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ pañcamaṁ.
analyzed: dantabhūmi suttam niṭṭhitam pañcama
translated: The fifth sutta is finished.
